The claim is supported by Habitat for Hu: an affordable home-building organization that partners with volunteers. They cited studies and reports that indicate South Florida ranks No. 1 in the gap between wages and housing.
One of the key reports cited is from the: which examined data from the American Community Survey conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau. This report found that housing and transportation costs rose faster than income nationally, with South Florida topping the list of metro areas with the greatest disparity.
The Miami metro area: which includes Miami-Dade County, Broward County, and West Palm Beach, was specifically mentioned as having the highest percentage of income (40%) spent on housing for moderate-income households compared to other metro areas in the study.
Janet Viveiros: acting director of research at the National Housing Conference, confirmed that recent research shows the Miami metro area continues to struggle with affordable housing, particularly for low- and moderate-income households. She emphasized that even those who are working still face serious challenges in accessing affordable homeownership or rentals in the area.
